sn22.88:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
sn22.88:4.2: Now at that time Venerable Assaji was staying in a monastery built by a Kassapa, and he was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn22.88:4.5: and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him:
sn22.88:4.6: ‘Sir, the mendicant Assaji is sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn22.88:4.7: He bows with his head to your feet.’
sn22.88:4.9: ‘Sir, please go to the mendicant Assaji out of compassion.’”
sn22.88:4.10: “Yes, reverend,” those monks replied. They did as he asked.
sn22.88:5.1: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of solitude and went to Venerable Assaji.
sn22.88:5.2: Venerable Assaji saw the Buddha coming off in the distance,
sn22.88:5.3: and tried to rise on his cot.
sn22.88:5.4: Then the Buddha said to him:
sn22.88:5.5: “It’s all right, Phagguṇa, don’t get up.
sn22.88:5.6: There are some seats indicated by others, I will sit there.”
sn22.88:5.7: He sat on the indicated seat,
sn22.88:5.9: “Assaji, I hope you’re keeping well; I hope you’re alright. And I hope the pain is fading, not growing,
sn22.88:5.10: that its fading, not growing, is apparent.”
sn22.88:6.1: “Sir, I’m not all right, I’m not getting by. My pain is terrible and growing, not fading,
sn22.88:6.2: its growing is apparent, not its fading.”
sn22.88:6.3: “I hope you don’t have any remorse or regrets?”
sn22.88:6.4: “Indeed, sir, I have no little remorse and regrets.”
sn22.88:6.5: “I hope you have no reason to blame yourself when it comes to ethical conduct?”
sn22.88:6.6: “No sir, I have no reason to blame myself when it comes to ethical conduct.”
sn22.88:6.7: “In that case, Vakkali, why do you have remorse and regrets?”
sn22.88:6.8: “Sir, before my time of illness I meditated having completely stilled the physical process. But now I can’t get samādhi.
sn22.88:6.9: Since I can’t get samādhi, I think:
sn22.88:6.11: “Assaji, there are ascetics and brahmins for whom samādhi is the essence, equating samādhi with the ascetic life. They think:
sn22.88:7.1: What do you think, Assaji? Is form permanent or impermanent?”
sn22.88:7.6: They understand: “… there is no return to any state of existence.”’
sn22.88:7.7: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t relish it.
sn22.88:7.10: If they feel a painful feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t relish it.
sn22.88:7.13: If they feel a neutral feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t relish it.
sn22.88:7.15: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they feel it detached.
sn22.88:7.16: If they feel a painful feeling, they feel it detached.
sn22.88:7.17: If they feel a neutral feeling, they feel it detached.
sn22.88:7.18: Feeling the end of the body, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body.’
sn22.88:7.19: Feeling the end of life, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life.’
sn22.88:7.20: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life is over, everything that’s felt, being no longer relished, will become cool right here.’
sn22.88:8.1: Suppose an oil lamp depended on oil and a wick to burn.
sn22.88:8.2: As the oil and the wick are used up, it would be extinguished due to lack of fuel.
sn22.88:8.3: In the same way, feeling the end of the body, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body.’
sn22.88:8.4: Feeling the end of life, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life.’
sn22.88:8.5: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life is over, everything that’s felt, being no longer relished, will become cool right here.’”
